Hallucinogenic drugs such as L.S.D., D.M.T., D.E.T., mescaline, psilocybin, methylated amphetamines (for example, ecstasy, S.T.P., M.D.A.) and cocaine can loosen the Assemblage Point and shift it in any direction. Many factors, such as personality, guilt, fear, health and one’s environment, will determine the direction and the degree of the shift of the Assemblage Point. However, in users of such drugs, the general direction of the shift is towards the left side. The larger the dose, the greater the shift and the more exaggerated the experience becomes.

When the effects of the drug have worn off, the Assemblage Point can relocate at a detrimental position and angle. Since the Assemblage Point location determines how we behave and how we feel, using these drugs can cause a sudden change in personality with the physical and psychological symptoms associated with the new location manifesting. Shifting the Assemblage Point back to the position before the drug was taken will generally correct the situation. Patients suffering long term Assemblage Point misalignment caused by drugs may require several shifts over a period of months. They may also require supportive psychological therapy to assist in the stabilisation of their Assemblage Point.

Anyone experimenting with or researching the effects of hallucinogenic drugs should be aware that their Assemblage Point location will be affected. Therefore they should keep detailed records of the Assemblage Point location, before and after drug experiences. Clinicians using these types of drugs for psychological and psychiatric research will accelerate their research programmes by taking into consideration the patient’s Assemblage Point location. Without such considerations, research and therapies using hallucinogenic drugs are irresponsible and unethical....From the Published Book: The Catalyst Of Power - The Assemblage Point Of Man - By Jon Whale. This was the best thing I ever tried, I felt so good, so confident, and had so much fun. I had an addiction not to serious lets say vaping or something like that, I didn't need it for a whole month after tripping. And I think with once a month or two use of it and my addiction would've faded away as you realize what is really beautiful about this world and yourself. Biggest thing it's been teaching me is to be in control of my environment and to prioritize my self before others, not selfishly but not me last and everyone else first.  Each time I have a good time and it tells me b4 we meet again you need to fix this, and gives me a specific problem to solve in my life. When I tell people how good it is they think i'm talking about the high, yes that is the best one of those i've ever experienced but that's not why I use drugs. I use them to get a different perspective and to explore my consciousness which we hide so subliminally without knowing it. Also if you have problems it will make you deal with them, and it won't let you say  maybe tomorrow or not right now. However it also has your back like it's not going to let you get hurt, it's like you talking to you or at least it is for me.  Does some stuff get scary yes but be curious and remember you want answers more than you are scared of the unknown. Also I took 2 and some vitamin c which boosts the effects and it was kind of like watching TV, the dramatic show is only on for about 5-10 minutes b4 you get a commercial break and a point of homeostasis for being that high.  N you will get used to it because it lasts 8-12 hours so there's no getting out once you're in but that serotonin should prevent you from worrying about too much.  All my hallucinations were good except for one where I kept feeling like there was someone behind me, I kept looking around and nobody would be there, and then I got mad and I said yo what's your problem. Then the room went red like a horror movie and these alabaster dudes in black capes were all around me they pointed to me and said you.  And then it ended and I took a thc break to calm down.  But I think what it was saying that I am my own problem, and the fear of being judged was represented by the shadowy figures.  And if you have a bad experience try to rationalize it and understand where it's coming from and what it means, that will make it more enlightening then it will frightening.

HPPD isn't "tripping forever" it's due to psychedelics effecting a part of the brain that deals with vision, do enough and you develop HPPD, also known as visual snow. It's as if some light snow or tv static is there, but can worsen when doing drugs or alcohol, it's not permanent. Decreasing substance use for a while gives your brain time to heal.

Taking acid in the 60's taught me that you are either on a good trip or a bad trip, although you could also be in a twilight zone of both. If you think positive and look on the brighter side of life, It's exhilarating. I have had trips where i laughed so long that my stomach was sore in the morning, but if you succumb to your fears, it can be hell. Overdosing or taking impure LSD can also increase the risk. First time, take less rather than more, pretend you are going on a real trip. Be relaxed and when it comes on, let it wash over you like a wave. Just ride it and keep your spirits up. It will accentuate anything you do. You will peak for a time and then gradually wind down. During the peak, you can become like ADHD. You might listen to music, then want to look at the sky, because you want to experience everything. It will basically reflect your state of mind or even things you read or think about before you take it. It kinda gently overpowers you. Take smooth breaths and relax. Be with people you trust. Don't take it too often cos it does loosen you up a bit and you can become a little too free for this limited world. It's best in small doses and done infrequently. A peaceful country setting is much preferable to the business of a city, especially for first timers. Being in a tranquil setting and appreciating the beauty of the world. I think it definitely expanded my mind. It helps you think outside the boxes the world tries to put you in.

The first time I tried LSD me and my long time friend put on minecraft music, looked at each other, bawled our eyes out uncontrollably with happiness and hugged.

The second time I tried it he was growing scary demon horns, I thought I was stuck in my house forever in like a “day on loop” Groundhog Day film, and decided to smash my brand new 65” TV.

Take that as you will, but I’d also like to note that during the second trip my housemate turned the tv off, we both zoned out in the pitch black of my house which wasn’t the tidiest it could’ve been, I’d also been drinking beforehand.

I guess the point is, be careful, plan your trip in advance, ensure that you have a safe environment to go to with things such as light, music, and a drink available (for me it was my bedroom) and try to remember that you’re in control. If things are going bad, change your scenery so that your brain can readjust.

Also, be careful, fear the worst when turning to acid: western Buddhism and veganism :0

I was dropping daily for a while heavy like 3_4 tabs a day but my body was so used to it then I ran out. Got a new batch a month later at 3 pm on a Monday. Took 3 tabs so used to taking that much and ended up dying inside my own head. Not dying like bad but I couldn't escape my thoughts. Turn off my brain, panic attacks are real but luckily I had mental fortitude that night really only because I didn't want a hospital bill and by the time I realized oh shit this isn't turning off And I have work in 4 hours on Tuesday. Constipated calling a friend to help me through it but it was late. I couldn't tell where I began and ended. The loss of perception of time and self, like losing your compass I couldn't tell if up is up or down is down because you become everything. Sit in a chair your the chair, you lose the feeling of self and that's so hard for your brain to process when the compass is always on when your sober. The detailed death images were terrifying, kaleidoscopes of death, magots, and more. But telling yourself it'll be ok and accepting it was the only escape. Since then I can imagine things is much better detail. Like strait imagination got retuned and even though I'm a bad artist, I can't draw for shit I've found that I can draw way better now though. Overall Id say it was a pretty enlightening trip. Made me fear death a little less, which is one of my darker fears, and to accept life as is. Enjoy yourself, careful and stay frost

I've done LSD before and I can say it was a weird experience. I had experience taking ALL kinds of things before so I had gained a pretty sharp clarity and could be on pretty much anything in the book but appear normal if I wanted to. So I was intrigued by the drug. When I tried it, there were no "hallucinations" in the way you think about them. You don't see things that aren't there or any of that. My mental acuity was sharp, I was not "high". What I noticed though is that it completely eliminates the mental filter that we all take for granted. Normally, there are all these things going on around us and we have those things slotted into a sort of "matrix of meaning". A table is a table, a chair is a chair, we subconsciously know what these things are and our brain is constantly slotting them into their proper little box through this filter. Our brain is running all of subroutines in the background. But LSD completely eliminates that filter. I would see something and it wouldn't get slotted anywhere, it's like that inherent understanding of what was around me was gone. If I wasn't absolutely concentrating on an object and remembering what it's regular role is, it could "change" into something else. For a brief moment, I thought my laptop cables were moving in the corner of my eye and I assumed it was a snake. Just for a split second. I had to try very hard to keep my "normal" state of thought, it was much more difficult maintaining that than anything I'd ever been on. It took an incredible amount of effort. So what I'm saying is that this is not normally a drug you want to try if you're by yourself, ESPECIALLY without experience.. Some people could flip out and do something to hurt themselves.

What LSD does, in the end, is that it reveals what is inside of you. Without your brain filtering everything based on experiences/habits/etc., the only thing that's left is your subconscious thoughts brimming to the surface and those inform you of what's going on around you. It's an incredible journey of self-discovery because it can reveal things inside of you that you didn't know where there, which is why this drug can be used to cure people from all kinds of addictions and trauma by revealing the deep-seated reasons for those problems in the first place.

If you’re a long time drinker or you have any mental illness/concussion/brain damage, LSD affects your brain in terrifying ways. It did for me. I took a huge dose for my first time (NEVER DO.) Every emotion I had was amplified 100x. I got offended by anything and scared of my surroundings. The next part is my blood pressure was out of control and I overheated for hours. I got stuck in thought loops and forgot what I had been saying. Within 40 minutes, the visual hallucinations came on. So all three of those aspects can make someone who doesn’t know the way they think absolutely terrified. Be really careful and always test and weigh a substance and take small doses. Don’t make my mistake if you value your sanity.

Lsd end game

Lsd is like a video game. It has a start and a finish. Literally has an end game boss, a major boss battle of epic proportions, with an absolute joy and satisfaction awaiting its completion.

Once this boss is defeated, it all ceases. Every single thing stops. All visuals, all extra sensations, all vibrations, all changes to sound, the immense field of energy felt within and around you, everything stops. You can 100% defeat the LSD game, in an instant once the final battle with your biggest Demon, your own self, the curtains are drawn, the play ends, the credits roll, you collect the extra achievements and expanded dlc and its result is permanent, its result settles in your soul, FOREVER.
Lsd literally stops working after the endgame level battle, with a literal Thanos onslaught of epic proportions
The first time it will happen would be mid trip or towards end of trip. Then the next time you do Lsd, because of “self muscle memory” you renter the state it, then lsd doesn’t work from the get go, you can take 8 tabs or 15 tabs and it’s like 1/2 a tabs experience.
Everything that used to happen completely ceases, every amazing, infinite fractal stops, colours calm down completely, sound stays normal, your body is under no energetic or vibratory influence.
You’d think you broke something. You will be confused. You’d have had some serious battles with yourself to get to this point, yet from here something new starts, a new journey filled with such wonderful joys experiences, here in you play the complete game and get the epic achievements and top it off the Expanded DLC, once the extras in the state of normality are collected, that prize is permanent in daily life.


If you have been using lsd for sometime and are still getting this amazing lovey visuals and experiences, then you need to up your game. All you are doing is playing the same exact levels of the game over and over, You are not taking it seriously. Lsd is a tool for the mastery of self, if it’s squandered on having just fun, partying or raving, it’s wasted completely. No person is fulfilled playing 1 repetitious level in a game. The satisfaction is the entire beautiful heartbreaking love story to its end, such a glorious ending of a game, written by the heavens itself, just for you, All for you.

Lsd is a serious tool, a tool to teach the human about its own absolute true nature. Tabbing 1/2/3/4 is a waste of time. Up thy game and start at 5 minimum. Up it towards 8-10 so all the serious lessons come into play if 5 isn’t doing it after 3 goes.
8-10 tabs is like 12 rounds with Mike Tyson and he ain’t got no gloves, so the self will get a serious kickboxing that it so truly needs.

Once you’ve defeated your final boss and completed the game, the veil breaks open, the curtains are drawn, the end credits roll and you will have attained somthing you cannot understand with the mind.
The first time it may occur, the cessation of all visuals and everything goes back to normal it would have been maybe half way through or towards the end of the trip.
At first one may not know what to do with this.
The next time you take a trip, you realise, it’s finished, all the visuals are gone, now you have 8-12 hours of semi 1 tab visuals, ie nothing. Barely a warping leaf just colour and contrast turned up in your field of vision.

Yet from here are the end game missions for those epic achievements, and in this state befalls a person different states of light knowledge. Experiences that are impossible to put into words, flow into your heart in the form of light. The ultimate truths of reality are revealed to you. There is an awakening that happens to your soul, so much tears and joy descend upon you.
The secret that is etched into your heart is and will remain permanent. Lsd or no lsd. A living knowledge settles inside you that cannot be shaken at all. The state you are in on the lsd at endgame is the state you live with permanently, but you really need to go to the end, you know when everyday you are in the same state of joy with complete power and control of ego mind.

Some will call this experience
Complete annihilation
True Oneness
nirvana
Buddha
Christ consciousness
The Muhamadan Reality
Awakening
Enlightenment
Freedom
Bliss joy ecstasy

If you are a player, then for once play the game properly, it must be taken seriously, follow basic steps :

Prepare the mind and listen to :
Alan watts , pramahansa yogananda, mooji, sadhguru, krishnamurti, shunyamurti, ram das, all religious scriptures are truth and one must start to understand the metaphors properly in their full wisdom which the alone teacher will make light of.

Intention: you main question and intention is “ who am I ?” (The above list should have prepared you)

When tripping, do alone or with one or two people who are in the same exact vibe.

Go to nature, have an open view and good lighting, take some seats.

For music only have classical (highly recommend Ludovico Einaudi) or just silence.

Maintain silence for periods of 1.5-2 hours at a time before taking again for 10-20 mins.

In your silent moments, try see that there are layers of reality and try to keep peeling them, these are layers of the mind. Keep going at it. Keep letting no no matter what.

If the body wants to fidget then tell it to shut up, you should know you have power over it. Keep persevering

At one point you will notice you are once with everything, keep going, then you will notice your face in everything, try to learn and understand the lessons of these states as you are in them ,keep going and then completely let go of all self. .
An experience will befall you that word will never do justice. This is where you learn your story, THE BEST STORY EVER TOLD.

Do 2 to 3 more trips and then learn within that state of no visuals etc how to master the state and learn where in the body it resides, once this FINAL EPIC ACHIEVEMENT is unlocked, is is permanent in you heart and lsd is a thing of the past, unless you just require extra downloads now, but that’s a whole new conversation, let’s leave it there as it should be enough for the freedom joy bliss and LOVE you’ve been looking for without knowing it, but you will know it.

But 9+ months after my series of experimentations with LSD, I no longer experience such negative, overwhelming feelings of hopelessness and doubt, and my anxiety attacks occur far less frequently (rarely ever) and subside more easily.  Everyone has individual brain chemistry, and many may not experience the miraculous outcomes that I have.  But to the margin of people like myself who will (and I truly believe my case would be a commonality in such a world), and to the thousands of inmates incarcerated for related offenses, we owe clinical, unbiased research.
To this day Acid was still the best decision I’ve ever made for my mental. Changed me as a person and made me realize nothing even matters. Just enjoy life

I think you should consider the Vietnamese subtitle! It does not translate the "default mode network" (DMN). That could lead to a big misunderstood while newspapers say it can lead to psychosis. Decreasing blood flow in DMN can be achieved by expert mindfulness meditators.

There are many researches about this, one of them by Harvard Medical School. When DMN lit up, our brain will stay out of this world. We get distract. So stable it can help us comeback and stay focus. But in the real world, not everybody can always see things in a positive way.

If a human with negative mind, stabilizes the DMN and comebacks to the real world may cause them panic. Because DMN to them usually their only shell of a beautiful world. I think LSD can be a solution but it has more to do with the mindset, more than the drug itself.

Before the monks achieving this stage, meditation help them set the right mindset. So when completely stable the DMN forever, everything in this world can be welcome, including fears. All is friend. They never get distract by the DMN, completely connect with the world.

One concept I’d like to share from my research in LSD, I’ve studied the process of how our brains store memory through the use of synapses in our brain, as the saying goes, “Synapses that fire together, wire together, synapses that fire apart are wired apart” so given the info, as well as from my personal experience. LSD is capable of causing large portions(if not all) of the the synapses in your brain to communicate, causing them to strengthen their communication ultimately increasing your brains ability to problem solve in ways never thought of before. As well as an aid to keeping the brain from deteriorating or losing information from lack of synapse stimulation... I’ve not seen this concept much spoken upon but I truly believe it to be facts

Okay. So. I have two tabs of LSD. Or “LSD”. From someone online who I’ve never met in person. This individual has sent me marijuana on numerous occasions and all turned out fine. This person also claimed that they took the same LSD from the same batch that I was given.

I learned that the liquid test kits that react with colors doesn’t completely tell you it’s LSD, but only something similar to the molecule structure that LSD has. I’m not about to send my tabs in for testing, and I don’t wanna give it to someone else just because of the risk of it potentially not being actual LSD.

The other thing I’ve been told is that LSD is tasteless and orderless. But that’s also a risky way of testing, as once you taste it, it’s already on its way to your bloodstream.

Any ideas? Advice? It’s Hallowicked 2020 and I wanna try it. I’ve had these two tabs since Summer.

I love all your videos but I was slightly dissapointed at how little you spoke about the negative sides of it. My experience with LSD was horrible. So much that I fell into a hole and get seasonal depression which last up to six months at a time. I barely survived my last 'dark phase' where my thoughts became that dark and and plain suicidal. My anxiety became a much bigger problem than it was before already. During the trip I was confused, paranoid and anxious. Which was in no way fun nor enjoyable.. I know a handful of people who have suffered similar experiences.
My point is not to fish for sympathy or attention, I just want people to understand that LSD is a dangerous drug. Maybe not that much on your body but on your mental wellbeing, especially if you are prone to mental illnesses.

Know how people say "I saw dragons." Bullturds. At least from my perception, I haven't seen anything of an inanimate object. My first time this asshole from the skate park used an eyedropper to pour out what was like a 3/4 teaspoon at most from what I saw the amount. I can't say but it looked like that much. Just a puddle of acid on my palm. Pressed it in my mouth, under the tongue, and licked it all up. It wasn't until 5 minutes my mouth was numb and my body felt a soothing fuzz down to my toes and scalp. Let's go 10-15 minutes in, black was purple, white was green/pink, some were blue. Just vaguely. And things started to breath soothingly, waving and twist. Like wet acrylic paints collaborated. 40 minutes later I can't see. I couldn't speak because it was unspeakable. Everything in front of my eyes were jolting like a stuck clock. I must have been peaking for 3-4 straight hours. I lost all perception of time and reality, and didn't sleep for over 24-hours. And I always sat up-right with this ridiculous overwhelming body high. A complex between of ascending to descending. The most spiritual connection to existence. And that was all it were. Just a self-ideology of unanswered questions of how and why we are conceived to existence. It was monumentally phenomenal in ways I can't express.
Word of advice, just stick to a half tab at least if you're going to try it out. I haven't done acid anymore since but I'm willing to try it again (CAREFULLY).

I tried Microdosing. I took half a T and I felt so weird at first. My eyes felt like lasers and I could see my surroundings fully with peripheral vision. Patterns created physical euphoria. Walks are amazing. Music is amazing. Light felt amazing. I felt so tall and lifted it’s like I weighed 60 pounds (I weigh 160) I had much more energy. But you’re conscious is stuck in a certain way. It’s like being in a mental fishbowl of acid and part confusion (as a first timer). But once you overcome the uncomfortable part you start to enjoy looking at yourself. I was dancing and trying on all these clothes I never wore before, changed my hairstyle up for fun. It sort of does improve the quality of life. You just have to put your mind to it, very deep into it, you can get lost in your own thoughts very very fast so find something to clean or trippy to watch otherwise you’ll just freak out. The acid needs to work with visuals (look at cool shit on TV) otherwise it’ll start to feel weird (like wtf did I just take?)

I experimented with mushrooms and LSD for the first time this year. I took 3.5 grams of mushrooms the first week and what I experienced was an OK 3 hour trip. I enjoyed it for the most part, but I didn’t like using my phone, being inside, or looking at myself in the mirror. The next week I tried a tab of LSD. I enjoyed the LSD experience a lot more. I liked what I saw in the mirror this time. The trip lasted a long time, maybe 8-12 hours. The next day my friend and I took another tab early in the day before going to the beach. The beach was very nice. My only complaint is the lower back pain I had during the trip, which I read up on and is common due to vasoconstriction. I enjoyed the experience with LSD. I did not enjoy the mushrooms experience as much.

Everyone else: When I took LSD, I was able to feel the music, not just hear it. I felt the sound and emotion from the instruments rush through every part of my body and consume me in an embodiment of creative energy. When I became happy, I understood what happiness really is, and how fundamentally important it is in our lives. When I felt scared, I understood fear in it's most primal form, and that there truly is nothing in this mortal realm to be afraid of. And when I was with someone I loved, I truly felt love. I learned in that moment what love truly is. I felt as though that love would never leave me, because it shouldn't leave me. If that feeling of love were to leave me, I would feel incomplete. I have HPPD, i wouldn’t go as far as to say it’s a “never ending trip”, it’s more so a slight filter of a trip over your vision 24/7. For example here are some of my symptoms (this is only my subjective experience, not everyone’s symptoms are the same) Anyways, I see grainy static on everything all the time, some call it “visual snow” it’s like the static you see on an old TV for me, it just kinda fills my vision and it’s always faintly there moving, i also see colors different, it’s like my vision is always moving, its weird and hard to explain, sometimes i see tracers too, also i kinda have a sensitivity to light, they can appear really bright to me. Also now when i smoke weed it’s like full on acid trip visuals, i’m 18 and have had this shit since like 15, but don’t worry i’m off da drugs. Hope u gained insight by reading this✌🏼

correction: HPPD is in fact real but it is not what you explained. Yes, it is possible that once you've finished tripping you'll still maybe see some visual distortions (in the form of tracers or a dulled filter over everything) but these subside with time and WILL NOT last forever. It is simply IMPOSSIBLE to get stuck in a trip because on a very real level, once the drug has ran its course and exited your body, you will no longer be tripping.


Flashbacks however are complete bullshit, yes its possible that after psychedelic use other drugs like marijuana for example can seem more psychedelic. But without that magical little substance called Lysergic Acid Diethylamide, you can not have a physical trip. and no you will not randomly break into a full on trip completely sober thats just unrealistic

Saying HPPD is a never ending trip is misinformed. People with HPPD are not in the mindstate of a trip, they can function and think as normal. They only have an impaired visual perception like experiencing colour as more vivid, everything having a grainy texture, seeing flashes of light at moments, seeing objects vibrating etc. It is possible but unlikely that symptoms will last your whole lifetime, but don't be surprised if it takes months to wear off. If you are worried, talk to your doctor, and make sure you inform them of the substance you've used. I'm not an expert in any way, not even an "expert by experience", I'm just here to point out a flaw in this video.

I’m gonna be trying acid for the first time this weekend with a friend (sleepover in my room, at night where no one can bother us). If you have any advice or tips (or wanna recommend something fun to do during our trip) for us, please lmk :)

Good acid trip: you recognize that your body is a conduit for spiritual energy, you appreciate beauty in everything, and ego death occurs when reality becomes so abstract that nothing will surprise you (at that point all things are witnessed objectively and you're very introspective)
Bad trip: your entire existence is fight or flight. Everything you can sense wants to kill you. You are a panicked animal.

Ultimately LSD will magnify your feelings. If it makes you feel better, of my 5 acid trips only one was bad, and I stayed outdoors to overcome my fear. I knew deep down that if I overcame a literal living nightmare, the rest of my life would be cake. And it has been.
My advice: try LSD (though I personally prefer Psilocybin. I mean hey, LSD is cheaper and lasts longer)

Your explanation of "flashbacks" and HPPD is way off. HPPD is a disorder that causes the visuals of a psychedelic substances stay longer than intended. This usually goes away over time but can be quite stressful for those going through their daily lives. Flashbacks don't exist at all and are actually episodes of PTSD which can make it feel like you're going into a bad trip.

Most of this video was fantastic except where you cover “flashbacks” and hppd. Flashbacks are simply just not real. What is actually going on is a form of ptsd that can come about from heavy use. It’s not something that just happens, it’s the same as in a veteran hearing certain sounds and suffering a breakdown. HPPD is slightly different from the way you describe it and is so little of a threat to anyone using lsd. With this said however there is other dangers that you didn’t cover that pose more of a risk, such as “fake tabs” where compounds such as research chemicals are put on tabs to make easy money and these compounds are potentially harmful. I don’t advise everyone go out and take psychedelic substances as they can have different effects on everyone’s mental state and may not be what you expected. I do however wish for the stigma around these compounds to change or disappear. The comparison between substances like LSD, DMT and psilocybin and harder, synthetic drugs is pretty outdated and wrong. When amphetamines and opioids are seen as equal to things like tryptamines and cannabinoids is pretty stupid. Do your research and don’t take drugs overall. i dont think people dive too much in the cons, as it is overflowed by pros. I tried LSD once, and got unbelievably bad anxiety after the trip in 4 months, which was unforgiven. it was unarguably the WORST 4 months in my ENTIRE life. and i regret it so much. my anxiety got so bad, that i considered suicide for a whole week. And im not the only one. when i first got my anxiety i googled a little bit, and found out that it is apparently a common thing that can happend to some people, and i have never heard of it before i tripped. some people have it in a few weeks, and some months. all i heard about was people had their best momenst in life through a trip, but that wasnt in my case. LSD isn't for everyone, and PLEASE, take that i consideration, before you try it. Pshycadelics may not be physical harmful, but it can damn well be mentally harmful. BUT, im not saying that is does not have some pros! i have heard unbelievably stories about people who cured their depression, anxiety, social-anxiety and trauma. but i have also heard some who went the opposite direction. it defiently has some potential, but it needs research. what i am saying is that pshycadelics is really a gamble, but who knows, you may get the best moments in your entire life through a trip :)

I would def recommend mushrooms as a first psychedelic over acid (psyches aren't for everyone you have to deeply analyse yourself before tripping). Its a lot easier on the body and dosent last that long(4-6 hours). Tripping on lsd for 12 hours can get a bit much and can be distressing if the experience is displesant as well as anxiety over thinking the trip will last forever(its crossed my mind almost every one of my 9 trips around hour 10). I typically feel overly energized on acid and my emotions are a lot less stable which can be  very draining and overwhelming. Mushrooms feel very calm in comparison and allows you to ease into the experiance of tripping. They still can be intense however and must still be respected. They still are an experience, they have the potential to be as bad as they are good And a completely blissful trip isn't very realistic. Hey! As a person with HPPD, it really isn't like a "forever trip." you certainly don't feel the mental/emotional effects long after it's worn off, for me and for most people it's purely visual. And you don't really "see things" either, per say. I usually just have a slight overlay of visual snow or static, any kind of pattern begins to move slightly if I look at it for more than an instant, I get tons of eye floaters, occasional streaks of color in my vision, and when I get really stressed I get the visual effect of the walls and ground breathing. Pretty standard acid stuff, honestly, I kinda see it as a bonus at this point, life gets a lil less boring

Let's, please, stop perpetuating the myth of LSD "flashbacks."
To put it simply, you will NEVER just randomly have a full blown psychedelic experience. If that were true, then you'd bear witness to HUNDREDS of articles on how to trigger them and no one would buy LSD more than once.

The chemical compound LSD has an incredibly short half life and is completely dispelled from your body within a few days. Weed stays in you longer than LSD!!! Your body would never allow a foreign chemical like that to simply linger around in your system, so it does what it does best: breaks it down and kicks it out!!!

The closest things you'll get to a "flashback" would be things like using other psychoactive substances a short period after LSD (this is your brain simply being more prone to psychoactive substances and can even relate them to a psychedelic experience, however it will never be as intense as an actual one.), minor notices of certain feelings or visual effects that remind you of your psychedelic experience that last for very short periods of time (in reality, it's just you being more aware of these perceptual shifts that have happened your whole life, you simply associate them with the feeling of a psychadelic now.), and lastly, HPPD, which is nothing like a flashback.

Hallucination Persisting Perception Disorder is an INCREDIBLY rare (about 1 in every 20 psychedelic users will experience it) that you would know you'd have the day after your experience. It's not a full blown psychedelic experience, rather some minor visuals or "snow vision" and, it too, will run its course.

To all those thinking about taking any hallucinogenic drug, please try to inform yourself extensively before doing so and also take safety precautions, such as being at least close to a safe space and being sure you're definitely on board with consumption, as those are the most dangerous ways of wrong use. If anyone wants more information, feel free to ask. Anyone wanting to interview a user, i'd love to share my experiences.
Please stay safe and don't overestimate yourself, life is too valuable to toy with this kind of drugs. I certainly don't mind you taking LSD, but do it in full knowledge of what you're actually doing and with all safety precautions available to you.

LSD does NOT cause "flashbacks". PTSD causes "flashbacks". Some people, usually very disturbed to begin with, can have such negative "trips" that they actually get a form of PTSD.

This accounts for around 1 out of every 100,000 LSD users, and the dynamics of the specific persons who are prone to these bad experiences makes it so that 1/100000 chance is actually a GROSS overestimation. I have taken LSD many, many times over two decades. I have never met a single person who had a negative experience that last more than a half hour of their trip. Having benzodiazepines on hand will also make sure any anxiety you may experience can't get out of hand.

REAL LSD, dosed correctly, is probably the safest recreational drug to take.

HPPD is NOT like a "never-ending trip". Regardless of all of the "tripping forever" urban legends out there, there is nothing you can do with LSD to make it never wear off. Even very large doses eventually come back down. HPPD is rather seeing visual distortions similar to the visual effects of LSD long after the effects have ended. This includes walls breathing slightly, tracers, increased "floaters" in the eye or graininess in vision. Most of the time it is not bad enough to cause problems but there are a few cases where people found it uncomfortable.

There is actually very little evidence of "flashbacks". The only scientific study I found was one from the nineties where government researchers tried to prove the amount of homeless people in this one city was because of a hippie concert 30 years ago.

I found LSD's cognitive effects to be pretty mild and never once felt out of control even with the time looping. The biggest drawback is that heroic doses tend to bring on aheavy body load, and trips can become too uncomfortable physically to be enjoyable. The sensory enhancement is quite amazing, but the aesthetic sensitivity does get a bit old after the first few times. Also thought becomes much more "agile" and doing tasks like computer programming or mathematical analysis become extremely fun and engaging. Unfortunately most work produced under this state of hyper awareness typically has to be heavily revised later because it turns out to be an over complicated mess to a sober brain. The most fun thing to do on LSD in my opinion is sports, or whatever your favorite technical physical activity is. You will feel like you have superhuman vision and coordination while tripping, so don't make a habit of it or else playing without tripping will quickly become nothing but frustrating.

LSD is a consciousness expanding agent. It does not produce 'hallucinations' any more than a dream, or my imagination. LSD allows a person to see things previously invisible to him. One can see the vitreous humor of the eye for example. This apparently clear fluid is actually a mass of protoplasm, with long strands of cells, double cell walls, nucleoids, and other cellular organs. The strands are much like long stands of opaque vermicelli. The eye has chanced upon a method of focussing on the interior of the eye, and become in effect, a microscope. This is not a hallucination.
There is an amazing amount going on around us that we do not see. We can actually see the wind blow, and I am not talking about dust or particulates in the wind, one actually see the refraction of light in the moving air. One can see sounds. They are in effect, like the wind, moving the air and causing vibrations in the light which can be seen. Out of body experiences, visits to space, visits to the interior of the body, skin sight, [the ability to see out of the back of ones head], the ability to see spirits and angels, and to actually visit heaven and hell are common, and certainly, and absolutely, are not hallucinations.
In this time of institutionally fostered stupidity, we cannot afford to continue pseudo science in regards to this wonderful tool for healing.
If LSD were used correctly, with proper instruction, and in a proper environmental setting, it could cure most human ills. It cures alcoholism, it cures criminal behaviour, it cures racism, and it cures war. Best of all it makes a person heal the planet.

People don't "get high" on LSD. High, tripping, rolling, etc. are all different feelings with different specific characteristics. To be high is to be relatively functional and in tune with the reality that we all agree to be the real reality. Tripping is quite different, while still being able to perform many tasks efficiently, but perhaps with much more brain activity happening that's unseen to any observers.

Perhaps you should double-check the flashback thing though. A day after using psychedelics like LSD or psilocyn/psilocybin, getting high with cannabis could be more intense than usual, straddling the line between being high and being back on a shorter trip of reduced but still notable intensity.

I like most of what I see on this channel, but I have some problems with the presentation, here, ranging from glancing inaccuracies to misrepresentations approaching disinformation. If the purpose of the video is to provide factual information, it doesn't do so consistently, and if the purpose is to raise awareness about the possible positive/negative effects of LSD use, people who watch this as a source will walk away with some false ideas that could easily skew overall perception. I should also preface this by saying that the video gets much right, and correctly attempts to mollify concerns about LSD causing psychosis or leading to suicide, for example. But for such a short video, on such a misunderstood topic, it doesn't take due care.

1) You don't get bloodshot, droopy eyes when you use LSD; you don't look stoned (0:10). This optic makes LSD use look frivolously recreational, which it certainly is not for many, if not most individuals who use the compound. Similarly, at 1:15 the figure looks stoned, bloodshot, and strung out. Simply not true to reality. In reality, your pupils dilate. That's it.

2) I take serious issue with the use of the word "high" in this context (0:22). Again, "getting high" makes LSD sound trivial or juvenile. It also unnecessarily introduces confusion about the subjective effects. This isn't marijuana we're talking about, and the effects of these two drugs are dramatically different. Unique nomenclature has been developed to describe psychedelic experiences. Use it.

3) "A single dose of LSD is measured in 1/100,000 of a gram" (0:40). What's a "dose"? A microgram is one millionth of a gram. I'm not sure if this is simply a factual error or if they're using an arbitrary, undelineated dosage that's equivalent to one one hundred thousandth of a gram, but this is confusing, at least. Why not just describe the microgram as a unit of measurement?

4) Right after the pericope in which the video describes the potential clinical, therapeutic benefits of LSD (which I should stress is accurate, and the presentation of that aspect is well-constructed), it again lapses into talking about a microdose being "1/10 of a recreational dose". First, there is no typical dose of LSD, so the statement means virtually nothing. Second, this pejorative language has the effect of deprecating the status of LSD in the minds of viewers. Would we or should we tether ego dissolution, positive upshifts in meaningful personality traits, and subsequent quality of life improvement to "recreational" dosing? I don't believe that's either accurate or helpful for the ongoing discussion.

5) The warnings about flashbacks and HPPD beginning at 2:50 are significantly exaggerated by virtue of omitting relevant statistics. Flashbacks are very, very rare, to the degree that many people believe the concept is mythical. I'm not saying they don't happen, but I've never had one, and have never known any enthusiasts, even experienced ones, that have had had even a single flashback. HPPD is similarly extremely rare, and is likely the product of serious abuse of LSD.

Okay, let's clear up the flash back stuff, I've had HPPD. It goes away! So this is a hunch but it feels right: let's say you're tripping. and you begin to have thoughts that you don't want to think (your fears, shit from childhood, etc) with your brain in a heightened state. If you cannot train yourself to walk away from those thoughts under that state, then you will have anxiety, which will be amplified into what people call a "bad trip". It's not a roll of the dice, "oh this time's gonna get me". You do it to yourself, and if you are not prepared to face those fears that you have brought up by making new neural connections and using introspection, this causes the brain to create a false ego. This is an ego that quickly learns how to handle the new experience/information and it is often carried into life after the trip is over. Along with this ego comes what people refer to as flashbacks, but there's a lot of misconstrued info about what flashbacks are. You aren't suddenly fighting a dragon in the middle of the street when you have a flashback. It's one of two things, or both: you get this alert feeling and it's like your body is pumping anxiety juice through every tube, the space around you may be a little warpy (because of the user's mind, or they've been doing alot of hallucinogens). There are a couple of bodily symptoms, like numbness in the face (especially the nose, close to your eyes) but beyond that the other part would be just straight up hallucinating patterns. This is about what it's like :https://gfycat.com/DelayedAngryErmine
These symptoms go away with a slew of different things: Time, exercising your brain, laying off hallucinogens (including decreased cannabis, or just dropped altogether), and getting into some supplements that aid in the restoration of your brain, like Lion's Mane. The symptoms don't last forever, and the best thing to remember is that you have the ability to develop hppd, so be careful in the future. Also, for people attempting to heal themselves: think about how people have to deal with withdrawing of SSRI's and other serotonergic drugs. If you research it, you'll see a common problem of hallucinating, not in a trippy way, but like giant tesla coils are in your peripheral vision and they're firing electricity all over your visual field. Gabanergic drug withdrawal also causes auditory and visual hallucinations. Flaxseed Oil, Krill Oil and Fish oil are supposed to be great to help build your brain back up faster so look into those supplements if you're trying to get out of the woods and back into reality.

1. LSD and Acid are the same substance

LSD, also known as acid is a psychedelic drug famous for altering your perception and creating hallucinations. But how does it actually works and what is the effect on your body and more importantly, your brain? Lysergic acid diethylamide was first synthesised in 1938 from the fungus that grew on rye. In 1943, the inventor Albert Hofmann accidentally touched some to his mouth, got high and became the first person in the world to learn about psychedelic properties of LSD. Research on the drug took place in the 50s and 60s, but as recreational use began to spread, psychedelic drugs were made an illegal Schedule I drug in the US and research programs were haulted. While other drugs are dosed in grams, a single dose of LSD is measured in one 100,000th of a gram, which is one 10th the mass of a grain of sand. LSD affects multiple brain receptors such as the dopamine receptors, adrenergic receptors, and glutamate receptors. But most research is on the stimulatory serotonin receptor 5H2TA. LSD hits the receptor at an unexpected angle causing it to fold over the LSD creating a lid. The LSD is then trapped which makes this receptor continually fire, causing you to hallycinate. Your body responds by sucking the 5TH2A receptor into the cell in order to degrade the LSD, but this can take up to 12+ hours to happen which is why the high can last so long. Recently, LSD research has seen a revival and using contemporary neural imaging techniques, researcher fond that the drug causes parts of your brain to communicate in unique ways, especially in the visual cortex potentially explaining the vivid and complex hallucinations. There's also decreased blood flow in the default mode network, correlating to strong changes in consciousness, characterized as ego-dissolution, described as a feeling where the boundary that separates you from the rest of the world dissolves. Many people report this feeling brings a sense of reconnection with themselves, others, and the natural world. In fact, a study on 20 healthy volunteers receiving 75 micrograms of LSD saw that 2 weeks after being dosed, they scored higher for the traits of optimism and openness, with increased creativity and imagination. This has lead researchers to consider LSD as a therapy for patients with death anxiety and life-threatening illnesses. Researchers found that 12 months after treatment, patients reported a reduction in anxiety and rise in quality of life, as the drug helped them restructure their habits and worldview. It is also why the trend of microdosing in emerging, where a person takes one 10th of a recreational dose of LSD, attempting to skip the hallucinations and instead experience heightened alertness, energy, and creativity. Although LSD is non-addictive an researchers rate it as significantly less dangerous than other drugs like cocaine and heroin, there's still and extreme lack of scientific studies to the explain the widespred microdosing trend and even experienced hallucinogen users sometimes experience bad trips producing irrational fears, paranoia, and panic attacks. LSD can also cause flashbacks, where month after the drug has worn off it can feel as though you're experiencing the effects of the high all over again. In some extreme occasions, people have developed Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disorder, which is like a never-ending trip. Thinking that LSD can lead to psychosis and the risk of suicide are overstated. The 14% of participants in the US national survey who had done psychedelics in the life had no increased risk of developing psychosis, depression, or suicide attempts, but the new research arond LSD's potetial positive effects is also very young. So this might not be a trip you want to take. Wanna learn more about your brain on drugs? comment_text:
If you have never tried LSD and are looking to, i will leave you with this bit of information
Try Psilocybin mushrooms first if possible, it's a great introduction
Always do psychedelics with people you trust
Try to always have a sitter (sober person)
The trip lasts for the better part of 12 hours, and you will usually start peaking at around 45min to 1 hour after dosing
Try to have some outside time wether it's day or night. Don't just stay indoors the whole time. A change of scenery will accentuate your trip and you will learn things about yourself.
Good music is key, try to make some playlists beforehand.
And finally, be safe and have fun out there.

Just wanted to take a moment and give my experience incase anyone's in edge with it. (If the FBI is reading this... it's a joke) I'm currently 17 but I took acid at the age of 16. Haven't done anything else but smoke so it was definitely a big jump. I took one tab(tested it and everything). I was with a friend and we had three guys watching after us. It took around 30 minutes to really hit me. I remember we were at this little grass field and I was just staring up and the clouds were really intense. I felt the wind differently, the grass, the air, the sun felt amazing. It made everything feel good. I was really not used to all these feelings so I talked a lot for the beginning of my trip but as time went on I just started to enjoy it more and more. The best part of it was that we had a group of some friends come through while the sun was setting and we just smoked. One of the most relaxing times in my life. I remember just feeling the sun and the beauty of it all. I plan on taking it again once I finish with school and feel ready again. It really changed my personality in a good way. I used to be really lazy with my studies and work. I got a knew job getting paid $18 and hour and have almost all A's. Not saying everyone should expect this but just my experience. If you feel ready for it then I recommend you do it. Just remember-"Never underestimate your drugs." Best of luck to all

Flashbacks from LSD are rare and if they do happen they are normally just the head space of the trip and not the visuals. Also HPPD is not a never ending trip, it is characterized by slight visuals such as floaters, visual snow, and minor tracers and isn't a full blown trip. HPPD isn't permanent except for a few cases which I'm pretty sure are very rare and further more HPPD isn't very common either and mostly happens with frequently use.
Another big topic completely missed on this video is LSD and schizophrenia. All though LSD does not cause schizophrenia, it can potentially bring out the mental illness early on or make it a lot worst. If you have any blood relatives that have schizophrenia you may want to reconsider taking it. Stay safe.

I would just like to point out that HPPD is NOT like experiencing a never ending trip. In fact, a symptom of HPPD is flashbacks, so it's not continual thing. I would go as far as to say it's a form of PTSD with the heightened anxiety, the intermittent (not continual) flashbacks, and the irrational fears (also anxiety-related). Flashbacks usually take visual form; as in you might see tracers or flashes of blue/white light. But it's never like actually being under the effects of the drug. It's typically treatable and most often lessens in severity with time without treatment.

Just a forewarning, if you do try LSD just make sure you're ready because the world is wayyy different after. You notice that you had all the power this whole time to fix all the problems and situations you worried about for years. Your eyes are open to decrepit power structures and conditioning. You'll most likely see things from a different perspective, giving rise to creative intelligence and a new respect for things you've taken advantage of. While this new perspective sounds awesome for the most part (which it is) there does come a point where you sort of question the whole nature of reality and realize that maybe the way we have been taught to have a successful "way of life" isn't all that grand, which might give you the free agency to change aspects of yourself, to create a life more suitable to the you on the inside, not so much the "you" that society made.

My last LSD trip was something I wasn't expecting, it was powerful, harsh, beautiful, and uncomfortable all in one and it has profoundly changed my life. I noticed that many of the relationships I had were toxic, my living situation was unsuitable and everything in my life (which I assumed didn't bother me) were devastating at a subconscious level, and LSD helped to bring these issues to the surface - one of the reasons why LSD and other psychoactive substances should be used in therapeutic settings. This is a great video, however It's both a blessing and curse to realize the complex nature of reality,

I really want to talk about this with someone experienced so i'm just going to drop it here too. It was originally a reply to some comment but i didn't get any answer so...enjoy:  I'd like to describe the effects of high doses of LSD with a trip report. It was actualy the first time i took the substance. I had gotten 9 tabs of LSD for like 50 bucks one day. They were sold as 150ug. I had taken mushrooms a few times prior to this. With mushrooms my favorite dose for a proper but handable trip was 3 dried grams alone in a dark room. So i did a bit of research and figured out that 100ug of LSD should equal 1 gram of dried mushrooms. So as the incautious kid i was i took 2 tabs while laying in my bed at like 11 pm. I layed them under my thoung, listened to some music on my headphones and waited for it to kick in. The blotters i got were perfect. Just little tasteless pieces of paper. After 20 minutes my body began to feel different. It is really hard to describe in which way but everything was oversensitive and I was over the top aware of every little cell in it. It was like i had been just born into it and experienced it for the first time in my life. When this effect hit me i knew that this experience would lead me to full egodeath which i didn't intend to experience. I had had one egodeath on 5 grams of dried mushrooms so i knew that it was going to be way more intense than 3g. I don't even know why i knew that it was going to be intense but it was kind of just waiting for myself to die after that. My whole existence fest like being powercharged. When i hit the 30 minute mark i saw massive moving geometrical patterns flying in the dark infront of me. They built up danced in the air with the music i was listening to and everytime i moved my hand threw them i saw a trail of white light in the 3 dimensional patterns for a time after the movement. After 40 minutes it got too intense for me. The music danced like right in my head and the patterns started to appear outside of my normal field of vision. I had the music on the lowest volume but it felt loud and raging in my head while mixing with my thoughts and other senses. I started to freak out because i feared that my parents (where i was still living at the time) could come in without me hearing them. So i stopped the music and just listened to my thoughts for the rest of the trip. Everything got more and more intense. My whole world started to get streched in all different ways. The visuals were so intense that i couldn't see my room anymore. Things moved into each other creating new moving patterns. I had like a 360 degrees view where i could see the colourful patterns not only in my normal field of vision but inside my whole head and all around me. Even with like the back of my head i saw alot of red and green. I could experience every part of my counciousness with every sense. I could see my thoughts right inside myself and all of the outsideworld was inside myself too. All the time the patterns rushed through my head and I could hear them coming closer and louder and getting less loud when they went away. I started to loose my sense of self more and more untill i couldn't make a difference between my room and my body anymore. I experienced my thoughts in every different way one could imagine and saw them even in comic letters infront of me. Different parts of me experienced time in very different ways and it felt like i was thinking a lot of different things simultaniously. I thought about me driving crazy, questioned my whole existence and thought about the power and the legend of LSD and how it was so different as someone with no knowlege about it would imagine. While i did this the letters LSD flew around my room mixing with all the patterns in a beutiful terrifying way. I started to loose touch with reality more and more untill i really just concetrated on my thoughts and not to freak out about my situation. I felt like i could be sucked somewhere else every second and i had the fear of driving completly crazy for ever. Everything was loud and intense and moving and my thoughts where just this bright colourful moving patterns so it seemed all very bright and nothing like the dark room i was in at all. When i was at the peak of panicing my thoughts started to get very fast and loud to then just go really slow and like a tape you play slower goes really lowpitched my thoughts did too. And when they started racing again they got really highpitched. It felt so crazy and went on untill it was slow and fast simultaniously and I lost the concept of time. The moment it happened in felt streched into infinity and I felt like i was diing and being ripped apart into trillons of little pieces. I was sucked into some sort of weird place of nothingness for what felt like infinity. There was nothing but suffering and it was like a timeless hell for me. There was no memory. I didn't know what space or time or a human or life or anything else was. I didn't know why i was there or what i had been before. It was like i had been there forever and had the destiny to be there forever. I just felt so torchered and while it felt like there was no time at all i still had some concept similar to it. The only reason i know it is because after what felt like an infinity i accepted my destiny of a torchered being. At this moment i left this lonely place of nothingness and got to a place of everything. It was like a huge pattern which had everything that has ever existed and will ever exist inside it connected to each other in like a huge mandala. This place wasn't built out of matter but of vibrating streams of coulor. It is really hard to describe how i experienced it. I didn't really see it, i didn't really hear it i didn't really felt it in any kind of normal way you experience everydaylife in. It was like the language of my subconcious a mix of every sense. The nearest i can come to it is describing it as some sort of vibration. It was a melody, a theater and a piece of classical art all at once. The essence of existence where everything comes from. Something like what religous people would call god. It felt very mystical being one with all of existence. The history of an endless universe all space and all time every person that has ever lifed and will ever lifed was there. It was a beutiful place but because you could say that i was the place and there was really nothing else it was lonely ans lost too.  A pointless game of everything in the middle of nothingness. I was there for a very long time. I don't know how i left this place because all the things that are borders between events in our everydaylife didn't exist there. Somehow i was just reborn into my brain without knowing anything. But i had the concepts of space and time back. And over the next time i learned who i was and why the hell i was in this situation. It was a long time in which i felt like a brain, a place i couldn't leave but has all the information of the outsideworld in it. When i finally was abled to experience the world in a way similar to the sober mind the Sun was  already rising and my room which still looked very plastic and unreal was flowted by beutiful red light. I looked out of my window and saw the trees of the garden in a detailed and complex way. It was so beutiful (i know that i use this word very often in this context) and I was so happy to be in this place of human existense, to be sane, to be healthy, to have a loving and caring family, to have enough food and my whole existence seemed like a miracle of endless joy. After i came back i still felt very weird for the whole next day but the real experience only lasted for about 8 hours. There was not really a cut between the comedown and the afterglow. I have taken higher doses since then but i never had such an intense afterglow. I could here things hundreds of meters away like they were right inside of my head, i was really euphoric but also tired and unabled to concentrate properly untill evening.

Remember kids, when doing psychedelics, any worry, any anxiety, any fear that you have BEFORE you take the drug, can cause you to experience a "Bad trip". Don't try to take psychedelics as escapism, only take them when you're in a good, calm, exploratory mindset, and when you're open and curious towards new experiences. If you don't let go of your worries before you dose up, you're gonna have a bad time. If you do, you're going to experience the world in an entirely new way. Also, you won't always get hallucinations. My experience with LSD, in particular, was merely a euphoric experience of child-like wonder. Everything looked beautiful, because it was like I was only now really seeing it for the first time. Things that I always looked past, things that I never paid attention to because I'm always caught up in my own issues, now looked fascinating and unique and incredible, even though they physically hadn't changed from my perspective. It was like seeing the world through fresh eyes, and appreciating it like I hadn't in a long time. Also, keep a trustworthy sober friend nearby just in case you start freaking out. Just tell them what's worrying you, and trust them when they assure you that it's going to be okay. And try not to have too many stimulants with it, like caffeine and nicotine. Just from personal experience, they can mimic some of the signifiers of anxiety, which when your body is suggestible like it is under the effects of psychedelics, it can very quickly become real anxiety, at which point your brain will generate a reason for you to be anxious. As you can probably guess, this creates a feedback loop which ends with a bad trip. Be safe, friendos, and keep expanding your minds.

I am a person who battles with depression. I have made leaps and bounds in the past few years. I do have experience with LSD and other ego smashing drugs. Yes, it does seem to help when used responsibly. But I feel that it is the smashing of the ego that is the important factor here. In fact when I worked on getting my ego in check prior to the LSD experience, I tended to have a more positive trip. Meditation, prayer, altruistic behaviors all of these have helped me to battle depression. LSD can help but I most certainly would not rely on the drug on it's own. A person, healthy or not, will benifit from seperation from the ego. Go ahead and practice random acts of kindness, with an altruistic heart, and you will see positive results, with or without the drug. Also and maybe most importantly is human connection. Brotherly love. Try not to isolate yourself too much. Get out there and make, and maintain friendships. This is very important. Love your brothers and sisters as you would love yourself. ... It seems to be working for me.

flashbacks do not exist and the explanation of hppd is just wronnggg, but otherwise great video. I'll elaborate, most reported "flashbacks" are reported from consumers who took large doses in the wrong environment causing an extreme fear response which can in fact cause mild/moderate ptsd. comparing peoples "flashbacks" to a ptsd episode is like comparing apples and apples. hppd on the other hand, is when for the few days/weeks after a trip, the occasional static vision or colour alteration occurs but no psychological changes are reported and the effects are rarely anything more than mild. Only trip if you're in a good place in life and are in the correct environment(set and setting). LSD is amazing
